newsitem.title: NORWAY: Statoil in new drill project at Gullfaks.
newsitem.headline: Statoil in new drill project at Gullfaks.

text.p: Den norske stats oljeselskap AS (Statoil) said on Thursday it had begun drilling on the North Sea Gullfaks field using a new pioneering technique which is expected to extend the life of old producer wells.
The company's Status Weekly newsletter said the first sidetrack well to be drilled with coiled tubing had been started from the Gullfaks A platform.

The well is due to drill 300 metres horizontally, the sidetrack begins from the 2,500 metres deep A-10 well -- an old producer which has ceased to flow. Drilling horizontally makes it possible to reach a different part of the reservoir from that produced by the main well.
"If expectations are borne out, the new well will be able to produce oil for two to three years," Statoil said.
The state oil company said it had identified 34 new drilling targets to tap undrained sections of the reservoir. Twenty-three of these will be drilled with coiled tubing.
Statoil said the technique was economic because it uses an existing well.
